message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest exercise-induced asthma, and short-acting β2-agonists are the first-line treatment for this condition. Systemic corticosteroids may be used in severe cases, but not as the initial treatment. Aminophylline is not recommended as a first-line treatment for asthma. Avoidance of exercise is not a practical solution as the patient is likely to experience breathing problems during physical activity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, which can be treated with short-acting β2-agonists. Systemic corticosteroids and aminophylline may be used for more severe cases, but short-acting β2-agonists are the first-line therapy. Avoidance of exercise alone is not a sufficient treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB). Short acting β2-agonists are the first-line treatment for EIB. Systemic corticosteroids are not indicated for EIB as the effects take too long to develop. Aminophylline has been used in the past for asthma but is not recommended as a first-line treatment for EIB. Avoidance of exercise would be an option, but it may not be practical or necessary for all patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB), also known as exercise-induced asthma. Short-acting β2-agonists are typically the first-line treatment for EIB. Systemic corticosteroids are not appropriate for acute treatment of EIB, and aminophylline is not commonly used for this condition. Avoiding exercise altogether is not necessary or recommended, as exercise has many health benefits. Instead, the patient can use medication to control the symptoms and continue with exercise.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing symptoms of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, which is commonly treated with short-acting β2-agonists like albuterol. Systemic corticosteroids are typically used for more severe cases, and aminophylline is no longer recommended as a first-line treatment. Avoidance of exercise is not a viable option for a young, active patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of difficulty breathing, cough, and wheezing suggest exercise-induced asthma (EIA). Short acting β2-agonists are recommended as first-line treatment for EIA, while systemic corticosteroids and aminophylline are not recommended for acute treatment. Avoidance of exercise is not the best option as it can lead to deconditioning and worsening asthma symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, which is best treated with short-acting β2-agonists like albuterol. Systemic corticosteroids and aminophylline are not first-line treatments for this condition. Avoidance of exercise is not a sustainable solution for a young, active person.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest exercise-induced bronchoconstriction. Short-acting β2-agonists are the first-line therapy for managing acute episodes of bronchoconstriction. Systemic corticosteroids are not recommended for acute management. Aminophylline may be used as an additional treatment in severe cases, but it is not the first-line therapy. Avoidance of exercise is not a viable treatment option for a young and otherwise healthy patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, and the best treatment for this is short-acting β2-agonists. Systemic corticosteroids may be used in more severe cases, but they are not the first-line treatment. Aminophylline is no longer recommended for the treatment of asthma. Avoidance of exercise is not a practical solution for most people.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest exercise-induced asthma, and short acting β2-agonists are the first-line treatment for this condition. Systemic corticosteroids are used for more severe cases, while aminophylline is no longer routinely used for asthma treatment. Avoidance of exercise is not a viable solution for a young and active patient.
